metadata.title: 5 Ways You Can Learn Computer Vision | by Richmond Alake | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: 5 Ways You Can Learn Computer Vision
metadata.description: Discover effective methods of Learning Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, and Computer Vision.

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Hands-On Machine Learning With Scikit-Learn, Keras & TensorFlow
computer vision techniques for motion analysis of a quadruped

all_paragraphs: And don’t let anyone tell you otherwise.
I am not just saying that because I currently work as a Computer Vision Engineer or because I studied an MSc degree in Computer Vision (clearly, I’m biased).
Picture yourself having dinner with some friends, and one of your friends says: Hey *insert your name here*, what do you do at your job.
“Facial recognition, body tracking, object detection… James Bond stuff…”.
And your friends stare at you in pure amazement and awe.
Disclaimer: The scenario above is most likely not going to happen.

But seriously, Machine Learning(ML) related fields such as Computer Vision(CV), Data Science, and Natural Language Processing(NLP), have become rather popular and fashionable during the previous decade.
This article will show you ways you can learn Computer Vision. So you too can join the cool club.
The methods I will be highlighting are methods I have personally used to gain some knowledge in ML and CV.
If you are familiar with any of the methods listed, feel free to skip directly to unfamiliar sections.
The price of getting an advanced qualification is increasing annually, but the value you get from obtaining a well-advanced degree qualification in an emerging field is almost priceless(sometimes).

I completed my MSc in Computer Vision, Machine Learning, and Robotics in 2019. I could’ve done without the robotics component of my course. Still, it turns out that the maths involved in working out the kinematics of a robot arm in 3D space is transferable to the calculation of the movement of objects in an augmented reality environment. This is relevant to me as I now work within a company that specializes in augmented reality.
My master’s degree enabled me to understand the theory behind popular computer vision techniques used for object detection, such as YOLO or RCNNs.

More importantly, I developed an academic awareness and mindset that has proven useful in my current role as a Computer Vision Engineer. In my studies, I read a good number of research papers on machine learning and computer vision. I still have to read research papers and understand and implement state of the art approach to common CV problems in my day to day job.
Learning Computer Vision through a masters degree is useful for the following reasons:
I realize not everyone has the time or funds to pursue a master’s degree, but the next best thing, and probably the cheaper option is to utilize the internet.
YouTube is a great learning platform, and I watch ML/CV content from popular channels to further my understanding and sharpen my practical skills.
Here are a few examples of YouTube channels that help me learn Computer Vision.
This channel content is second to none, and I can’t praise this channel’s creator enough.
Those who are familiar with 3Blue1Brown will agree with me when I say that he manages to teach topics that would take University lecturers hours of teaching in 15–20 minutes short videos.
The channel taught me the basics of Machine Learning and Neural networks and made maths simple.

Within machine learning, it is essential to understand topics such as linear algebra, calculus, and partial differentiation. When studying Neural Networks, it is crucial to understand the fundamental components of a neural network.
It is also essential to understand concepts such as backpropagation, vanishing gradients, and different neural network architectures.
The playlist below from 3Blue1Brown is a must-watch if you would like a simple explanation of the processes that occur within neural networks.
After understanding the basics of ML and Neural networks, you can dive into some academic sessions from Stanford that explains some common Computer vision techniques and algorithms.
This playlist provides you with the step by step academic knowledge of techniques that enable image classification, object detection, reinforcement learning, and plenty more.

Completing this playlist will provide you with a piece of general knowledge on Computer Vision algorithms, techniques, and approaches that are currently in use today in systems such as self-driving cars, facial recognition applications, etc.
Be sure to take notes and remember the key terms and concepts presented.

If you have a solid grasp of the theory and maths behind neural networks and some machine learning algorithms, you can move on to some practical projects and coding with a common machine learning library (PyTorch) and programming language Python.

PyTorch is a machine learning framework that provides people like you and me with the tools to implement and launch machine learning solutions and neural network architectures from the comfort of our laptops. PyTorch is most researcher’s framework of choice when it comes to implementing machine learning solutions.

Python is a modern programming language that has a place in various computing-related disciplines such as web development, server development, software development, etc. The language is prevalent and can is utilized for the implementation of machine learning solutions.

Deep Lizard’s video playlist will gradually take you through the process of neural network implementation. You will learn about topics such as the utilization of GPUs for neural network training, data structures (array and tensors); neural network layers; hyperparameters, and much more.
This section of the article contains some affiliate links.
Hands-On Machine Learning With Scikit-Learn, Keras & TensorFlow

If there is one book you should purchase to be prepared for machine learning in realistic environments, then Hands-On Machine Learning by Aurélien Géron is the holy grail for practical machine learning.
Most readers will have come across this book or its previous editions.

The first part introduces typical machine learning concepts and techniques such as gradient descent, support vector machines, feature engineering, and many more. The first part also introduces SciKit-Learn, a popular machine learning library, along with some common visualization and wrangling tools.

The second part of the book introduces concepts such as Convolutional and Recurrent neural networks and a variety of neural architectures. The second part of the book introduces TensorFlow 2 and Keras.

TensorFlow is a popular machine learning library that enables the implementation of neural networks and presents a suite of tools for common machine learning tasks such as visualization, deployment, and model optimization.
Deep Learning with Python by François Chollet is also a two-parter similar to the book mentioned previously.
The first part introduces the basics of the machine learning field. It focuses on explaining what the terms artificial intelligence, deep learning, and machine learning mean fundamentally.

The first part of this book seeks to build a brief theoretical knowledge of common concepts and topics machine learning practitioners come across frequently. Part 1 of this book covers an introduction to Keras, Jupyter notebook, NumPy, and more.

The second part focuses on practical deep learning by providing practical exercises and projects to implement with publically available datasets. Introductions to CNNs, RNNs (GRU and LSTM), and GANs are also covered in detail.
I will be honest here; every time I pick this book up, I have to blow the dust off it. This book is essential but is not as practical as the previously mentioned books.

Machine Learning A Probabilistic Perspective is a book that should be in every serious Machine Learning practitioner’s arsenal. The book encapsulates the mathematical and theoretical aspects of machine learning that form the basis of fundamental and advanced ML techniques.
Although the size and content of the book can be daunting, I use it to solidify knowledge on general topics before speaking or writing about them in a public domain.
One way to learn Machine learning or computer vision is by simply doing. This rule is applicable across a variety of fields.
I have learned more through undertaking and completing personal computer vision/ML projects.
The benefits of undertaking personal projects that I have experienced first hand are as follow:
I do not have an online portfolio, but I do have some projects where their codebases are hosted on GitHub.

For example, I worked on a project that involved the utilization of computer vision techniques for motion analysis of a quadruped. Through this project, I learned about pose estimation, transfer learning, object detection(RCNN), neural network implementation, and training with PyTorch, and so much more.
Popular libraries and frameworks for machine learning and deep learning (TensorFlow and PyTorch) have provided tutorials on some basic computer vision solutions and implementation for common tasks.
There are tutorials on face detection, pose estimation, image classification, transfer learning, and plenty more.

The purpose of the tutorials is not only to introduce you to the implementation of deep learning solutions but also to improve your familiarity with the frameworks or libraries method of data preprocessing, neural network implementation, training or other areas within the machine learning project pipelines, even model deployment.

Yes, believe it or not, Medium taught me a lot about Computer Vision. There are tons of articles on Machine Learning and Computer Vision on Medium. The sheer wealth of information on Medium is enough to keep you reading for days.
There are machine learning related tutorials, discussions, interviews, and reviews on Medium from intelligent, curious, and exciting writers.
On Medium I focus on two things. Consuming and Creating.

I’m not exaggerating if I mention that I have read over 50 Machine Learning related articles already in 2020 on Medium. Actually, change that number to 100. I have read articles from top writers and publications such as Towards Data Science and Becoming Human
By consuming content from other writers on Medium, I have learned how to communicate machine learning concepts to individuals who might not have heard about the topic.
I have developed a small presence within Medium and have managed to write 30+ articles to date, all related to Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning.
Writing about ML/CV concepts on a public platform encourages you to research deeply into topics in a manner that promotes and cultivates deep understanding.
In other to teach and inform, you must first know.
if you enjoyed this article and the content within it, then give me a follow as I write similar articles to this every week.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Machine Learning Content Creator with 1M+ views— Computer Vision Engineer. Interested in gaining and sharing knowledge on Technology and Finance
